title: 105_hr78
content: For purposes of subsection (a)(1), a joint resolution is described as a resolution of both Houses of Congress authorizing the United States Trade Representative to negotiate amendments to the Understanding on Rules and Procedures Governing the Settlement of Disputes related to XX. The second blank space in the curr_chunk is filled with the date of the affirmative determination submitted to Congress by the Commission, leading to a joint resolution authorizing the United States Trade Representative to negotiate amendments to the Understanding on Rules and Procedures Governing the Settlement of Disputes related to XX. The WTO Dispute Settlement Review Commission will present a report to Congress on XX. If negotiations do not lead to a satisfactory solution by XX, Congress will withdraw its approval of the WTO Agreement. The Trade Representative will negotiate specific rules and procedures, with dates filled in accordingly. The requirements for enacting a joint resolution related to the WTO Agreement are outlined in the procedural provisions. This includes transmitting the resolution to the President within a specified timeframe after receiving an affirmative determination from the Commission. The procedural provisions outline the requirements for enacting a joint resolution related to the WTO Agreement. This includes transmitting the resolution to the President within a specified timeframe after receiving an affirmative determination from the Commission. If the President vetoes the resolution, both Houses of Congress must vote to override the veto within a specific timeframe. The joint resolution related to the WTO Agreement can be introduced after an affirmative determination from the Commission and before the 90-day period. Any member of Congress can introduce the resolution, and expedited procedures apply. The Trade Act of 1974 provisions apply to joint resolutions related to the WTO Agreement. If a committee has not reported the resolution within 45 days, it will be automatically discharged and placed on the calendar. The Trade Act of 1974 provisions apply to joint resolutions related to the WTO Agreement. If a committee has not reported the resolution within 45 days, it will be automatically discharged and placed on the appropriate calendar. Finance and ways and means committees have specific rules for considering joint resolutions in the Senate and House of Representatives. The Trade Act of 1974 provisions apply to joint resolutions related to the WTO Agreement. A joint resolution may only be made on the second legislative day after the Member announces their intention. It is not in order to consider a joint resolution if the same matter has been previously adopted. This section is enacted by Congress as part of the rules of each House. The rules of each House allow for procedures that supersede other rules if inconsistent, with the recognition of the constitutional right to change rules relating to procedures at any time. SEC. 206. PARTICIPATION IN WTO PANEL PROCEEDINGS. The United States Trade Representative allows private US individuals with a direct economic interest in WTO panel proceedings to participate if they support the US Government's position. Regulations ensure their full participation and access to information. The United States Trade Representative provides access to information from WTO dispute settlement proceedings to relevant individuals and implements a protective order system for confidential information. Upon request, the Trade Representative consults with individuals on written submissions and may include them as advisory members in dispute settlement panel sessions. The United States Trade Representative allows special delegation members with unique knowledge to appear before dispute settlement panels through counsel. In cases involving confidential information, these individuals can only participate through counsel as part of the special delegation. SEC. 207. DEFINITIONS. For purposes of this Act, the terms "Appellate Body," "Adverse to the United States," "Dispute settlement panel," and "Dispute settlement body" are defined. The terms "Dispute Settlement Body," "Dispute Settlement Understanding," "Uruguay Round Agreement," "World Trade Organization," and "WTO Agreement" are defined in relation to international trade agreements. The term "WTO Agreement" refers to the Agreement Establishing the World Trade Organization signed on April 15, 1994.
